00001 # [QuEST](https://quest.qtechtheory.org)
00002 
00003 ## Introduction
00004 
00005 The **Quantum Exact Simulation Toolkit** is a high performance simulator of universal quantum circuits, state-vectors and density matrices. QuEST is written in C, hybridises OpenMP and MPI, and can run on a GPU. Needing only compilation, QuEST is easy to run both on laptops and supercomputers (in both C and C++), where it can take advantage of multicore, GPU-accelerated and networked machines to quickly simulate circuits on many qubits.
00006 
00007 QuEST has a simple interface, independent of its run environment (on CPUs, GPUs or over networks),
00008 ```C
00009 hadamard(qubits, 0);
00010 
00011 controlledNot(qubits, 0, 1);
00012 
00013 rotateY(qubits, 0, .1);
00014 ```
00015 though is flexible
00016 ```C
00017 Vector v;
00018 v.x = 1; v.y = .5; v.z = 0;
00019 rotateAroundAxis(qubits, 0, 3.14/2, v);
00020 ```
00021 and powerful
00022 ```C
00023 // sqrt(X) with pi/4 global phase
00024 ComplexMatrix2 u;
00025 u.r0c0 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag= .5};
00026 u.r0c1 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag=-.5}; 
00027 u.r1c0 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag=-.5};
00028 u.r1c1 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag= .5};
00029 unitary(qubits, 0, u);
00030 
00031 int[] controls = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
00032 multiControlledUnitary(qureg, controls, 5, 0, u);
00033 ```
00034 
00035 QuEST can simulate decoherence on mixed states, output [QASM](https://arxiv.org/abs/1707.03429), perform measurements, apply gates with any number of control qubits, and provides cheap/fast access to the underlying statevector. QuEST offers precision-agnostic real and imaginary (additionally include `QuEST_complex.h`) number types, the precision of which can be modified at compile-time, as can the target hardware.
00036 
00037 Learn more about QuEST at [quest.qtechtheory.org](https://quest.qtechtheory.org).
00038 
00039 ## Getting started
00040 
00041 QuEST is contained entirely in the files in the `QuEST/` folder. To use QuEST, copy this folder to your computer and include `QuEST.h` in your `C` or `C++` code, and compile using the provided [makefile](makefile). See the [tutorial](/examples/README.md) for an introduction, and view the full API [here](https://quest-kit.github.io/QuEST/QuEST_8h.html).
00042 
00043 We also include example [submission scripts](examples/submissionScripts/) for using QuEST with SLURM and PBS. 
00044 
00045 ### Quick Start
00046 
00047 Copy or clone this repository to your machine. E.g. in the desired directory, enter
00048 ```bash
00049 git clone https://github.com/quest-kit/QuEST.git
00050 cd QuEST
00051 ```
00052 at terminal. You can then compile the [example](examples/tutorial_example.c) using
00053 ```bash
00054 cp examples/tutorial_example.c .
00055 make
00056 ```
00057 then run it with
00058 ```bash
00059 ./demo
00060 ```
00061 and afterward, clean up with
00062 ```bash
00063 make clean
00064 rm tutorial_example.c
00065 ````
00066 The program will print information about your execution environment and some simple operations on a three qubit system. See the [tutorial](examples/README.md) for a better introduction. Additionally, run `cd tests` then `./runTests.sh` to test QuEST runs correctly in your environment, as specified in `makefile`.
00067 
00068 ## Documentation
00069 
00070 View the API [here](https://quest-kit.github.io/QuEST/QuEST_8h.html), and check compatible compiler versions [here](tests/compilers/compatibility.md).
00071 
00072 > For developers: To recreate the full documentation after making changes to the code, run doxygen doxyconf in the root directory. This will generate documentation in Doxygen_doc/html, and can be accessed through index.html in that folder. 
00073 
00074 ## Acknowledgements
00075 
00076 QuEST uses the [mt19937ar](http://www.math.sci.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/~m-mat/MT/MT2002/emt19937ar.html) Mersenne Twister algorithm for random number generation, under the BSD licence. QuEST optionally (by additionally importing `QuEST_complex.h`) integrates the [language agnostic complex type](http://collaboration.cmc.ec.gc.ca/science/rpn/biblio/ddj/Website/articles/CUJ/2003/0303/cuj0303meyers/index.htm) by Randy Meyers and Dr. Thomas Plum
00077
